|Ship range= |Ship capacity=*'''Passengers''' (as built):<ref name=Drechsel-v1-338>Drechsel, Vol. 1, p. 338.</ref> **327 first class **103 second class **80 third class **1,700 [[steerage]] *1904:<ref name=Drechsel-v1-338 /> **255 first class **115 second class **1,666 steerage *1921:<ref name = Bonsor-v2-567/> **350 cabin class **500 third class *1925:<ref name=NYT-1924-10-10 /> **675 passengers *1927:<ref name=Drechsel-v1-339 /> **450 first class **50 third class *'''Cargo''': **{{convert|4000|ST|t}}<ref name=NYT-1924-10-10 /> |Ship troops=1918:<ref name=Gleaves>Gleaves, p. 248</ref> : 3,500 : 3,900 after [[Armistice with Germany (Compiègne)|Armistice]] |Ship complement=1918: 449<ref name=DANFS-PM /> |Ship crew=*1904: 207–248<ref name=Drechsel-v1-338 /> *1921: 260<ref name=Bonsor-v2-567>Bonsor, Vol. 2, p. 567.</ref> |Ship armament=1918: 4 × {{convert|6|in|mm|adj=on}} guns<ref name=DANFS-PM /> |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Princess Matoika'' (ID-2290)''' was a transport ship for the [[United States Navy]] during World War I. Before the war, she was a {{sclass|Barbarossa|ocean liner}} that sailed as '''SS ''Kiautschou''''' for the [[Hamburg America Line]] and as '''SS ''Princess Alice''''' (sometimes spelled '''''Prinzess Alice''''') for [[North German Lloyd]]. After her World War I Navy service ended, she served as the [[United States Army]] transport ship '''USAT ''Princess Matoika'''''. In post-war civilian service she was '''SS ''Princess Matoika''''' until 1922, '''SS ''President Arthur''''' until 1927, and '''SS ''City of Honolulu''''' until she was scrapped in 1933.
Built in 1900 for the [[German Empire|German]] Far East mail routes, SS ''Kiautschou'' traveled between Hamburg and Far East ports for most of her Hamburg America Line career. In 1904, she was traded to competitor North German Lloyd for five [[cargo ship|freighters]], and renamed SS ''Princess Alice''. She sailed both transatlantic and Far East mail routes until the outbreak of World War I, when she was interned in the neutral port of [[Cebu City|Cebu]] in the [[Philippines]]. Seized by the U.S. in 1917, the newly renamed USS ''Princess Matoika'' carried over 50,000 U.S. troops to and from France in U.S. Navy service from 1918 to 1919. As an Army transport after that, she continued to return troops and repatriated the remains of Americans killed overseas in the war. In July 1920, she was a last-minute substitute to carry a large portion of the United States team to the [[1920 Summer Olympics]] in Antwerp. From the perspective of the Olympic team, the trip was disastrous and a majority of the team members published a list of grievances and demands of the [[United States Olympic Committee|American Olympic Committee]] in an action known today as the [[Mutiny of the Matoika|Mutiny of the ''Matoika'']].
After her Army career ended, ''Princess Matoika'' was transferred to the [[United States Mail Steamship Line]] for European passenger service in early 1921. After that company's financial troubles resulted in her seizure, ''Princess Matoika'' was assigned to the newly formed [[United States Lines]] and resumed passenger service. In 1922, the ship was renamed SS ''President Arthur'', in honor of the 21st [[List of Presidents of the United States|U.S. President]], [[Chester A. Arthur]]. When changes in U.S. laws severely curtailed the number of immigrants that could enter the country in the early 1920s, the ship was laid up in [[Baltimore]] in late 1923.
''President Arthur'' was purchased in October 1924 by the Jewish-owned [[American Palestine Line]] to begin regular service between New York, [[Naples]], and [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]]. On her maiden voyage to Palestine, she reportedly became the first ocean liner to fly the [[Flag of Israel|Zionist flag]] at sea and the first ocean liner ever to have female officers. Financial difficulties for American Palestine ended the service after three roundtrips, and the liner was sold to the [[Los Angeles Steamship Company]] for Los Angeles–[[Honolulu]] service. Following three years of carrying tourists and freight, the liner burned in [[Honolulu Harbor]] in 1930. She was deemed too expensive to repair and was eventually scrapped in Japan in 1933.
== Hamburg America Line == In March 1900 the {{HAPAG|first=long}} announced the plans for 22 new ships totaling {{GRT|150,000|disp=long}} at a cost of $11,000,000. One of the two largest ships announced was SS ''Kiautschou'' at an announced {{GRT|10,200}}.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9C02E0DE1E3CE433A25756C2A9659C946197D6CF |format=pdf |title=Hamburg-American fleet |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=25 March 1900 |page=14}}</ref> The ship was [[Keel laying|laid down]] at [[AG Vulcan Stettin]] in [[Stettin]], Germany (present-day [[Szczecin]], Poland).<ref name=Drechsel-v1-338 /> During her construction, {{HAPAG}} renamed the ship twice before finally settling on [[Kiautschou]], the German colony in China, as her namesake.<ref>Bonsor (Vol. 1, p. 408) identifies the two names as ''Borussia'' and ''Teutonia'', while Drechsel (Vol. 1, p. 338) gives them as ''Bavaria'' and ''Teutonia''.</ref> Built, along with sister ship {{SS|Hamburg||2}}, for {{HAPAG}}'s entry into the [[Reichspost#Deutsche Reichspost|Deutsche Reichspost's]] Far East routes, ''Kiautschou'' was launched on 14 September 1900, and sailed on her maiden voyage from [[Hamburg]] to the Far East on 22 December 1900.<ref name=Bonsor-v1-408>Bonsor, Vol. 1, p. 408.</ref>
The ship was {{convert|525|ft|m}} long and featured twin screws powered by two [[quadruple expansion]] [[steam engine]]s that generated {{convert|9000|hp}}. The liner also featured [[bilge keel]]s that helped stabilize her ride. On the interior, ''Kiautschou''{{'}}s first-class [[state room]]s were described as "light and large" and located in the center of the ship. She had two large [[promenade deck]]s, a music room, and a library. Her [[smoking room]] was at the rear of the upper promenade deck, and her large dining room featured a balcony where the ship's orchestra could serenade diners.<ref name=NYT-1904-04-06>{{cite news |title=Luncheon on a liner |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=6 April 1904 |page=16 }}</ref>
''Kiautschou'' sailed on the Hamburg–Far East route until May 1902. For one round trip that month, ''Kiautschou'' replaced fellow {{HAPAG}} steamer {{SS|Deutschland|1900|2}} on Hamburg–New York service,<ref>{{cite news |title=Hamburg America... |type=display ad |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=11 May 1902 |page=25}}</ref> calling at [[Southampton]] and [[Cherbourg]] on her eastbound trip,<ref>{{cite news |title=Shipping and Foreign Mails |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=4 May 1902 |page=23}}</ref> and at Cherbourg and [[Plymouth]] on her westbound return.<ref>{{cite news |title=Shipping and Foreign Mails |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=24 May 1902 |page=13}}</ref> After this one transatlantic excursion, ''Kiautschou'' was returned to Hamburg–Far East service.<ref name=Bonsor-v1-408 /> On 20 February 1904, in exchange for abandoning the mail routes shared with [[North German Lloyd]], {{HAPAG}} traded ''Kiautschou'' for Lloyd [[cargo ship|freighters]] ''Bamberg'', ''Königsberg'', ''Nürnberg'', ''Stolberg'', and ''Strassburg''.<ref name=Drechsel-v1-338 />
== North German Lloyd == North German Lloyd renamed the newly acquired ship ''Princess Alice'',<ref name=Bonsor-v2-566 /><ref name=Drechsel-v1-338 /> though the German spelling ''Prinzess Alice'' was widely used in contemporary press coverage and, often, by the Lloyd themselves.<ref name=Drechsel-v1-338 /> There is some confusion as to who exactly was the namesake of the ship. Edwin Drechsel, in his two-volume work ''Norddeutscher Lloyd, Bremen, 1857–1970'', reports that the ship was named equally for [[Princess Alice, Countess of Athlone|Princess Alice of Albany]] and [[Alice Roosevelt Longworth|Alice Roosevelt]].<ref name=Drechsel-v1-338 /> Princess Alice of Albany was a granddaughter of [[Victoria, Queen of the United Kingdom]], and the new bride of [[Alexander Cambridge, 1st Earl of Athlone|Prince Alexander]] of [[Teck]] in [[Württemberg]].<ref name=Eilers-215>Eilers, p. 215.</ref> Alice Roosevelt, daughter of the then-current U.S. President [[Theodore Roosevelt]], was nicknamed "Princess Alice" by the press, and had [[ship naming and launching|launched]] the racing yacht of [[William II, German Emperor|Kaiser Wilhelm II]], ''Meteor'', at [[Staten Island]] two years before.<ref>Drechsel, Vol. 1, p. 261. Alice Roosevelt had been further honored by the German Empire by the March 1902 renaming of former [[torpedo boat]] ''D2'' to ''Alice Roosevelt''.</ref> [[William Lowell Putnam]] gives the namesake as [[Princess Alice of the United Kingdom]], the daughter of Queen Victoria.<ref>Putnam, p. 145. Putnam states further that [[Princess Alice of the United Kingdom|Princess Alice]] was the wife of [[Frederick III, German Emperor|Kaiser Freidrich III]], apparently confusing Alice with her sister [[Victoria, Princess Royal|Princess Victoria]].</ref>
[[File:The-Princesses-Alice.jpg|thumb|left|SS ''Princess Alice'' was named for one or more of these Princesses Alice (from left): [[Princess Alice of the United Kingdom]], [[Princess Alice, Countess of Athlone|Princess Alice of Albany]], [[Alice Roosevelt Longworth|"Princess" Alice Roosevelt]].]] ''Princess Alice'' departed her new homeport of [[Bremen]] on 22 March 1904 for her maiden voyage under her new owners.<ref name=Bonsor-v2-566 /> After arriving in New York draped in flags and bunting, her dining room was the site of a press luncheon thrown by Lloyd staff celebrating her first arrival in that city.<ref name=NYT-1904-04-06 /> ''Princess Alice'' made four more roundtrips through early August, then shifted to Bremen–[[Suez Canal]]–Far East service, making her first Lloyd voyage on that route 31 August.<ref name=Bonsor-v1-408 /> ''Princess Alice'' would continue this pattern—sailing the North Atlantic during the heaviest-trafficked season and shifting to the Far East runs for the balance of the year—through 1910.<ref name=NYT-1904-04-06 /><!-- description of seasonal plans --><ref name=Bonsor-v2-567 /><!-- through 1910 -->
Throughout the rest of her Lloyd North Atlantic career she carried some notable passengers to and from Europe. In May 1905, for example, noted Baltimore [[gynecologist]] [[Howard Atwood Kelly]], one of the co-founders of [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]], sailed from New York;<ref>{{cite journal | title = Town & Country Calendar: Arrivals and Departures | journal = [[Town & Country (magazine)|Town & Country]] | date = 27 May 1905 | volume = 3080 | pages = 6 | location = New York | publisher = Stuyvesant | issn = 0040-9952 | oclc =5878257 }}</ref> author [[Hamilton Wright Mabie]] and his wife sailed from New York the following month.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Town & Country Calendar: Arrivals and Departures | journal = Town & Country | date = 8 July 1905 | volume = 3086 | pages = 3 | location = New York | publisher = Stuyvesant | issn = 0040-9952 | oclc =5878257 }}</ref><!-- 760905912 (3) --> American botanist [[Charles Frederick Millspaugh]] returned to New York aboard the German liner in June 1906,<ref>{{cite news |title=Ocean travelers |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=20 June 1906 |page=14 }}</ref> and retired U.S. Navy [[Rear admiral (United States)|Rear admiral]] [[Alfred Thayer Mahan]] did the same in June 1907.<ref>{{cite news | title = Rear Admiral Mahan returns |work=The Washington Post | date = 21 June 1907 | page = 3 }}</ref> Senator [[Augustus Octavius Bacon|Augustus O. Bacon]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[Georgia (U.S. state)|GA]]), sailed for Europe on 1 August 1908.<ref>{{cite news | title = Senator Bacon off for Europe | work = The Washington Post | date = 2 August 1907 | page = 3 }}</ref>
Prompted by the successful use of [[radio|wireless]] in saving lives during the sinking of {{RMS|Republic|1903|6}} in January 1909, and by proposed U.S. legislation (later passed as the [[Wireless Ship Act of 1910]]) requiring wireless for ships calling at U.S. ports, ''Princess Alice'' received her first wireless set in February 1909.<ref name=NYT-1909-02-12>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9803E6DC153EE733A25751C1A9649C946897D6CF |format=pdf |title=Wireless on more ships |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=12 February 1909 |page=1}}</ref><ref>Pierce, p. 690.<!-- wireless act provision --></ref> Operating with call letters "DKZ" on the 300 m band, her radio had a {{convert|250|mi|km|adj=on}} range.<ref name="wireless">{{cite book |url=http://earlyradiohistory.us/1909stat.htm |author=[[United States Navy|Navy Department]], Bureau of Equipment |title=List of Wireless Telegraph Stations of the World |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher= U.S. Government Printing Office |chapter=List of Merchant Steamers and Private Yachts |chapterurl=http://earlyradiohistory.us/1909stat.htm#vesselsworld |date=1 September 1909}}</ref>
{{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | width1 = 114 | width2 = 98 | image1 = AugustusOctaviusBacon.jpg | image2 = Alfred-Thayer-Mahan.jpg | caption2 = | footer = Senator [[Augustus Octavius Bacon|A. O. Bacon]], left, and retired Rear Admiral [[Alfred Thayer Mahan|A. T. Mahan]] sailed on ''Princess Alice'' in the 1900s.}} At 10:00 on 27 May 1909, loaded with over 1,000 passengers headed for Europe, ''Princess Alice'' departed the Lloyd pier in [[Hoboken, New Jersey|Hoboken]], New Jersey. As she neared [[The Narrows]] in a heavy fog, she steamed to stay clear of outbound [[Compagnie Générale Transatlantique|French Line]] steamer {{SS|La Bretagne||2}} and ran hard aground on a submerged rocky ledge near the [[seawall]] of [[Fort Wadsworth]] a few minutes after 11:00.<ref name=NYT-1909-05-28>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D04EEDD1E31E733A2575BC2A9639C946897D6CF |format=pdf |title=The Prinzess Alice aground in the bay |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=28 May 1909 |page=1}}</ref><ref name=NYT-1909-05-29><!-- time of grounding -->{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9902E5D6153EE733A2575AC2A9639C946897D6CF |format=pdf |title=Prinzess Alice sails |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=29 May 1909 |page=2}}</ref> After the fog lifted, it was revealed that the bow of ''Princess Alice'' had stopped some {{convert|5|ft|m|1}} from the outer walls of the Staten Island fort. [[Lighthouse tender]] ''Larkspur'' was the first ship to come to the aid of the ''Princess'', followed by [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] [[United States Army Quartermaster Corps|Quartermaster's ship]] ''General Meigs''<!-- not USAT Meigs or USS General M. C. Meigs --> and [[Cutter (ship)|revenue cutter]] [[USRC Seneca|''Seneca'']]. No passengers were hurt in the incident and it was determined there was no damage to the hull of the liner. But, despite the effort of attending ships, she remained stuck on the ledge.<ref name=NYT-1909-05-28 /> Eventually, after offloading {{convert|500|ST|t}} of cargo from her front [[Hold (ship)|hold]] onto [[lighter (barge)|lighters]] called to the scene, ten steam [[tug]]s and power from ''Princess Alice''{{'}}s own engines freed the ship at 01:47 on 28 May, almost 15 hours after running aground. The force required to free the liner was great enough that she was then propelled into SS ''Marken'', at anchor some distance away, damaging one of that ship's [[Fender (boating)|fenders]].<ref name=NYT-1909-05-29 /> After then making her way to the nearby [[New York City Quarantine Station]], ''Princess Alice'' anchored to reload her cargo, and by 09:05, she was underway again. However, she ran aground again in soft mud in [[Ambrose Channel]] at 10:15. This time she was able to free herself and proceeded on to Bremen, a little more than 24 hours late.<ref name=NYT-1909-05-28 /> This voyage was further marred by the apparent suicide of a despondent New York attorney on 30 May. The man, headed to the spa town of [[Bad Nauheim]] in Hesse, had previously suffered a [[nervous breakdown]] and was under the care of a doctor on board the ship at the time he jumped overboard.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F2061EF63C5A15738DDDAC0894DE405B898CF1D3 |format=pdf |title=Moss jumped from steamer |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=5 June 1909 |page=1}}</ref>
[[File:SS Princess Alice interned at Cebu, Philippines.jpg|thumb|left|SS ''Princess Alice'' is pictured during her internment at [[Cebu City|Cebu]], Philippines, c. 1914–1916.]] In May 1910, ''Princess Alice'' sailed her last North Atlantic passage for her German owners.<ref name=Bonsor-v2-567 /> Put permanently on the Far East route, she plied Pacific waters for North German Lloyd until the outbreak of World War I. In late July 1914, as war spread across Europe, ''Princess Alice'' neared her destination of Hong Kong with £850,000 of gold from [[India]]. Rather than face seizure of the ship and her cargo by British authorities there, ''Princess Alice'' instead sped to the [[Philippines]] and deposited the gold with the German Consul at [[Manila]]. Leaving the neutral port in under 24 hours, the ship then rendezvoused with German [[cruiser]] {{SMS|Emden|1906|2}} at [[Angaur]] before returning to the Philippines in early August and putting in at [[Cebu City|Cebu]] where she was interned.<ref name=Drechsel-v1-338 />
== USS ''Princess Matoika'' == On 6 April 1917 the United States declared war and immediately seized interned German ships at U.S. and territorial ports, but unlike most other German ships interned by the United States, ''Princess Alice'' had not been sabotaged by her German crew before her seizure.<ref name=Putnam-145 /> Assigned the Identification Number of 2290, she was soon renamed ''Princess Matoika''. Sources disagree about the identity of the ship's namesake, who is often reported as either a member of the Philippine Royal Family,<ref name=NYT-1921-01-30>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9F06EED8103FE432A25753C3A9679C946095D6CF |format=pdf |title=Transport in new career |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=30 January 1921 |page=E3}}</ref> or a Japanese princess.<ref name=Cutchins>Cutchins and Stewart, p. 64. Cutchins and Stewart are quoting Ernest R. Kinkle and John J. Pullam, historians of the [[113th Infantry Regiment]].<!-- a library/book search did not turn up any published work by either author; it may have been an unpublished or self-published work with a limited press run --></ref> Putnam, however, provides another answer: one of the given names of [[Pocahontas]] was ''Matoaka'', which was sometimes spelled ''Matoika''.<ref name=Putnam-145n32>Putnam, p. 145, note 32. Given that two other ex-German liners were renamed {{USS|Pocahontas|ID-3044}} and {{USS|Powhatan|ID-3013}}—after [[Pocahontas]] and [[Powhatan]] (her father)—this seems the most likely.</ref> The newly renamed ship was taken to [[Olongapo City]], {{convert|60|mi|km}} north of [[Manila]] and placed in the [[drydock]] ''[[Drydock Dewey (YFD-1)|Dewey]]'' at [[U.S. Naval Base Subic Bay|Subic Bay]] where temporary repairs were made. She then made her way to San Francisco, and eventually to the [[East Coast of the United States|east coast]].<ref name=NYT-1921-01-30 /> ''Princess Matoika'' was the last ex-German ship to be commissioned.<ref name=C&W-417>Crowell and Wilson, p. 417.</ref>
=== Transporting troops to France === Placed under the command of [[William D. Leahy]] in April 1918, the ship was readied for her first transatlantic troop run.<ref name=Leahy>{{cite web |url=http://www.history.navy.mil/faqs/faq36-2.htm |title=Fleet Admiral William Daniel Leahy |website=Naval Historical Center |publisher=[[United States Department of the Navy]] |accessdate=10 April 2008}}</ref> At [[Newport News, Virginia|Newport News]], Virginia, elements of the [[4th Infantry Division (United States)|4th Infantry Division]] boarded on 9 May.<ref name=Pollard-26>Pollard, p. 26.</ref> Sailing at 18:30 the next day, ''Princess Matoika'' was accompanied by American transports {{USS|Pastores|ID-4540|2}}, {{USS|Wilhelmina|ID-2168|2}}, {{USS|Lenape|ID-2700|2}}, {{USS|Antigone|ID-3007|2}}, and {{USS|Susquehanna|ID-3016|2}}, the British steamer ''Kursk'', and the Italian {{SS|Duca d'Aosta||2}}. The group rendezvoused with a similar group that left New York the same day, consisting of {{USS|President Lincoln|1907|2}}, {{USS|Covington|ID-1409|2}}, {{USS|Rijndam|ID-2505|2}}, British troopship {{SS|Dwinsk||2}}, and Italian steamers {{SS|Caserta||2}} and {{SS|Dante Alighieri||2}}.<ref name=C&W-609>Crowell and Wilson, p. 609.<!-- name of the ships --></ref><ref name=Gleaves-202>Gleaves, p. 202.<!-- nationalities of the British, Italian ships--></ref> American [[cruiser]] {{USS|Frederick|CA-8|2}} served as escort for the assembled ships, which were the 35th U.S. convoy of the war.<ref name=C&W-609/> During the voyage—because of the inability to finish serving three meals for all the men during daylight hours—mess service was curtailed to two daily meals, a practice continued on later voyages.<ref name=Pollard-27 /><ref name=Cutchins-65>Cutchins and Stewart, p. 65.</ref> On 20 May, the convoy sighted and fired on a "submarine" that turned out to be a bucket; the next day escort ''Frederick'' left the convoy after being relieved by nine destroyers. Three days later the convoy sighted land at 06:30 and anchored at [[Brest, France|Brest]] that afternoon.<ref name=Pollard-27>Pollard, p. 27.</ref> ''Princess Matoika'' sailed for Newport News and arrived there safely on 6 June with ''Pastores'' and ''Lenape''. Fate, however, was not as kind to former convoy mates ''President Lincoln'' and ''Dwinsk''. On their return journeys they were sunk by German submarines [[SM U-90|''U-90'']] and [[SM U-151|''U-151'']], respectively.<ref name=DANFS-PresLinc>{{cite DANFS |title=President Lincoln |url=http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/p11/president_lincoln.htm |accessdate=10 April 2008 |short=yes}}</ref><ref name=German-subs-p118>''German submarine activities'', p. 48.</ref>
[[File:Officers and crew of USS Princess Matoika, c. 1918.jpg|thumb|left|Officers and crew of ''Princess Matoika'' in 1918]] After loading officers and men from the [[29th Infantry Division (United States)|29th Infantry Division]] on 13 June,<ref name=Cutchins /> ''Princess Matoika'' set sail from Newport News the next day with ''Wilhelmina'', ''Pastores'', ''Lenape'', and British troopship {{HMT|Czar||2}}. On the morning of 16 June, lookouts on ''Princess Matoika'' spotted a submarine and, soon after, a torpedo heading directly for the ship. The torpedo missed her by a few yards and gunners manning the ship's {{convert|6|in|mm|adj=on}} guns claimed a hit on the sub with their second shot.<ref name=Cutchins-66>Cutchins and Stewart, p. 66.</ref> Later that morning, the Newport News ships met up with the New York portion of the convoy—which included {{USS|DeKalb|ID-3010|2}}, {{USS|Finland|ID-4543|2}}, {{USS|Kroonland|ID-1541|2}}, {{USS|George Washington|ID-3018|2}}, ''Covington'', ''Rijndam'', ''Dante Alighieri'', and British steamer ''Vauben''—and set out for France.<ref name=Cutchins-67>Cutchins and Stewart, p. 67.<!-- time of meeting--></ref><ref name=C&W-610-611>Crowell and Wilson, p. 610–11.<!-- list of ships --></ref> The convoy was escorted by cruisers {{USS|North Carolina|ACR-12|2}} and ''Frederick'', and [[destroyer]]s {{USS|Stevens|DD-86|2}} and {{USS|Fairfax|DD-93|2}};<ref name=C&W-610-611 /> [[battleship]] {{USS|Texas|BB-35|2}} and several other destroyers joined in escort duties for the group for a time.<ref name=Cutchins-67 /> The convoy had a false alarm when a floating barrel was mistaken for submarine, but otherwise uneventfully arrived at Brest on the afternoon of 27 June.<!-- date of arrival from C&W --><ref name=C&W-610-611 /><ref name=Cutchins-68>Cutchins and Stewart, p. 68.<!-- false alarm, uneventful nature of trip, time of day arrival --></ref> ''Princess Matoika'', ''Covington'', ''Lenape'', ''Rijndam'', ''George Washington'', ''DeKalb'', ''Wilhelmina'', and ''Dante Alighieri'' left Brest as a group on 30 June.<ref name=Feuer>Feuer, p. 63.</ref> The following evening at 21:15, ''Covington'' was torpedoed by [[Unterseeboot 86 (1916)|''U-86'']] and sank the next afternoon.<!-- time of attack--><ref name=Feuer /><ref name=DANFS-Cov>{{cite DANFS |title=Covington |url=http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/c14/covington-ii.htm |accessdate=10 April 2008 |short=on}}<!-- identity of U boat, sinking--></ref> ''Princess Matoika'' and ''Wilhelmina'' arrived back at Newport News on 13 July.<ref name=C&W-610-611 />
[[File:William Leahy cropped.jpg|thumb|right|120px|[[William D. Leahy]] (seen here c. 1945) earned the [[Navy Cross (United States)|Navy Cross]] while commander of USS ''Princess Matoika'' in 1918.]] Around this time, Commander Leahy left ''Princess Matoika'' to serve as Director of Gunnery Exercises and Engineering Performance in Washington.<ref>{{cite news | title = Next Navy Head Boasts Notable Service Career | work = The Washington Post | date = 27 December 1936 | page = M15}}</ref> For his service on ''Princess Matoika'', though, Leahy was awarded the [[Navy Cross (United States)|Navy Cross]]. He was cited for distinguished service as commander of the ship while "engaged in the important, exacting and hazardous duty of transporting and escorting troops and supplies through waters infested with enemy submarines and mines".<ref name=Stringer>Stringer, p. 95.</ref>
In the next months, ''Princess Matoika'' successfully completed two additional roundtrips from Newport News. On the first trip, she left Newport News with ''DeKalb'', ''Dante Alighiere'', ''Wilhelmina'', ''Pastores'', and British troopship {{HMT|Czaritza||2}} on 18 July.<!-- nationality--><ref name=Gleaves-202 /><ref name=C&W-613>Crowell and Wilson, p. 613.</ref> The group joined a New York contingent and arrived in France on 30 July. Departing soon after, the ''Princess'' returned to Newport News on 13 August.<ref name=C&W-613 /> Nine days later she departed in the company of the same ships from her last convoy—with French steamer ''Lutetia'' replacing ''DeKalb''—and arrived in France on 3 September.<!-- nationality--><ref name=Gleaves-202 /><ref name=C&W-615>Crowell and Wilson, p. 615.</ref><!--ships involved, dates --> ''Princess Matoika'' returned stateside two weeks later.<ref name=C&W-615 />
On 23 September, ''Princess Matoika'' departed New York with 3,661 officers and men accompanied by transports {{USS|President Grant|ID-3014|2}}, {{USS|Mongolia|ID-1615|2}}, ''Rijndam'', ''Wilhelmina'', British steamer ''Ascanius'', and was escorted by battleship {{USS|Georgia|BB-15|2}}, cruisers {{USS|Montana|ACR-13|2}} and ''North Carolina'', and destroyer {{USS|Rathburne|DD-113|2}}.<ref name=C&W-559-617>Crowell and Wilson, p. 559, 617.</ref> As with other Navy ships throughout 1918,<ref>[[Naval Historical Center|NHC]], ''Personal account by Rear Admiral William B. Caperton''; Gleaves, p. 190.</ref> ''Princess Matoika'' was not immune to the worldwide [[Spanish flu]] pandemic. On this particular crossing, two of her crewmen were felled by the disease as her convoy reached [[Saint-Nazaire]] on 6 October.<!--date--><ref name=C&W-559-617 /><ref name=Officers>Bureau of Naval Personnel, ''Officers and Enlisted Men...'', p. 729, 797. The source did not provide information on whether there were any deaths among Army personnel aboard.</ref><!-- location of arrival, deaths--> After her return to the U.S. on 21 October, she departed New York once again on 28 October, arriving in France on 9 November, two days before the [[Armistice with Germany (Compiègne)|Armistice]].<ref name=C&W-619>Crowell and Wilson, p. 619.</ref> In all, she carried 21,216 troops to France on her six trips overseas.<ref name=Gleaves-248-49>Gleaves, p. 248–49.</ref>
=== Returning troops home === With the fighting at an end, the task of bringing home American soldiers began almost immediately.<ref name=Gleaves-31>Gleaves, p. 31.</ref> ''Princess Matoika'' did her part by carrying home 30,110 healthy and wounded men in eight roundtrips.<ref name=Gleaves-248-49 /> On 20 December, 3,000 troops boarded her and departed France for Newport News, arriving there on 1 January 1919.<ref name=WP-1919-01-02>{{cite news | author = [[Associated Press]] | title = Matoika lands 3,000 | work = The Washington Post | date = 2 January 1919 | page = 4 }}<!--Arrival date, updated wounded tally--></ref><ref name=WP-1918-12-25>{{cite news | title = Transport with 3,000 due at Newport News January 2 | work = The Washington Post | date = 25 December 1918 | page = 4 }}<!-- departure date, units, Menoher--></ref> Among those carried were [[Major General (United States)|Major General]] [[Charles T. Menoher]], the newly appointed chief of the air service, and elements of the [[39th Infantry Division (United States)|39th Infantry Division]].<ref name=WP-1918-12-25 /> The ''Matoika'' arrived with another 2,000 troops on 11 February.<ref>{{cite news | title = Troops reach Newport News | work = [[The Atlanta Constitution]] | date = 12 February 1919 | page = 12 }}</ref>
{{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=right|image1=Greeting troops aboard USS Princess Matoika 20 December 1918.jpg|image2=Boat drill on USS Princess Matoika, April 1919.jpg|width=280|caption1=A combined Army Navy band greets soldiers boarding ''Princess Matoika'' to return to the United States in December 1918.|caption2=Returning soldiers rest during a boat drill on ''Princess Matoika'' in April 1919.}} In March 1919, ''Princess Matoika'' and ''Rijndam'' raced each other from Saint-Nazaire to Newport News in a friendly competition that received national press coverage in the United States.<ref>{{cite news | title = Chicago troops reach U.S. after race over ocean | work = [[Chicago Tribune|Chicago Daily Tribune]] | date = 21 March 1919 | page = 4 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = "Old Hickory" boys go to Charleston | work = The Atlanta Constitution | date = 21 March 1919 | page = 10 }}</ref> ''Rijndam'', the slower ship, was just able to edge out the ''Princess''—and cut two days from her previous fastest crossing time—by appealing to the honor of the soldiers of the 133rd Field Artillery (returning home aboard the former [[Holland America]] liner) and employing them as extra [[stoker (occupation)|stokers]] for her boilers.<ref name=Harlow>Harlow, p. 195, quoting Kent Watson from ''History of the 133d Regiment''.<!-- No Worldcat listing for quoted work. Perhaps work quoted was unpublished? --></ref>
On her next trip, the veteran transport loaded troops at [[Saint-Nazaire]] that included nine complete hospital units. After two days delay because of storms in the [[Bay of Biscay]], ''Princess Matoika'' departed on 16 April, and arrived at Newport News on 27 April with 3,500 troops.<ref name=Brown>Brown, p. 145–46.</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Many Georgia boys reach Newport News | work = The Atlanta Constitution | date = 28 April 1919 | page = 6 }}<!--number of troops--></ref> Shifting south to [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]], South Carolina, the ''Matoika'' embarked 2,200 former German [[prisoner of war|prisoners of war]] (POWs) and hauled them to [[Rotterdam]].<ref name=Hagedorn>Hagedorn, p. 163.</ref> This trip was followed up in May with the return of portions of the [[79th Infantry Division (United States)|79th Infantry Division]] from Saint-Nazaire to New York.<ref>{{cite news | title = Pennsylvania troops arrive | work = The Washington Post | date = 27 May 1919 | page = 10 }}</ref>
In mid-July, ''Princess Matoika'' delivered another load of 1,900 former German POWs from Charleston to Rotterdam; most of these prisoners were officers and men from interned German passenger liners and included Captain Heinler the former commander of {{SS|Vaterland||2}}. One former POW, shortly after debarking in Europe, presciently commented that "this [was] no peace; only a temporary truce".<ref name=NYT-1919-07-19>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9F07EED61E3BEE3ABC4F52DFB1668382609EDE |format=pdf |title=Repatriated Germans arrive at Rotterdam |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=19 July 1919 |page=3}}</ref> After loading American crews of returned Dutch ships, ''Princess Matoika'' called at [[Antwerp]] and Brest before returning to New York on 1 August.<ref name=NYT-1919-07-19 /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A07E0DF1738E13ABC4A53DFBE668382609EDE |format=pdf |title=Shipping and Mails |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=2 August 1919 |page=18}}<!--date of arrival--></ref>
The ship departed New York on 8 August for her final roundtrip as a Navy transport.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9F0CEFDC1338EE32A25754C0A96E9C946896D6CF |format=pdf |title=Shipping and Mails |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=7 August 1919 |page=9}}</ref> She departed Brest 23 August and returned to New York on 10 September. She was decommissioned there on 19 September, and handed over to the [[United States Department of War|War Department]] for use as a United States Army transport.<!-- final arrival, decommissioning dates--><ref name=Gleaves-248-49 /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C07E1DE153AE03ABC4E53DFBF668382609EDE |format=pdf |title=Shipping and Mails |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=6 September 1919 |page=20}}<!-- departure from Brest--></ref>
== USAT ''Princess Matoika'' == As her career as an Army transport began, ''Princess Matoika'' picked up where her Navy career had ended and continued the return of American troops from Europe. After returning to France she loaded 2,965 troops at Brest—including [[Brigadier General (United States)|Brigadier General]] [[Wilds P. Richardson|W. P. Richardson]] and members of the [[Polar Bear Expedition]], part of the [[Allied intervention in the Russian Civil War]]—for a return to New York on 15 October.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A0DE1DC1038EE32A25750C1A9669D946896D6CF |format=pdf |title=Shipping and Mails |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=13 October 1919 |page=27}}<!-- departure from Brest--></ref><ref>{{cite news | title = General say Reds killed 82 Yankees in Russia | work = Chicago Daily Tribune | date = 16 October 1919 | page = 7 }}</ref> In December, Congressman [[Charles Hiram Randall|Charles H. Randall]] ([[Prohibitionist]]-[[California|CA]]) and his wife sailed on the ''Matoika'' to [[Puerto Rico]] and the [[Panama Canal]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Society | work = The Washington Post | date = 19 December 1919 | page = 7 }}</ref>
On 5 April, ''Princess Matoika'' carried a group of 18 men and three officers of the U.S. Navy who were to attempt a transatlantic flight in the rigid airship ''[[R38 (ZR-2)|R38]]'', being built in England for the Navy. Several of the group that traveled on the ''Matoika'' were among the 45 men killed when the airship crashed on 24 August 1921.<ref>{{cite news | title = A transatlantic flight |work=The Times | date = 1 April 1920 | page = 15 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |website=Naval Historical Center |url=http://www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-p/id2290-o.htm |title=USN ships – USS Princess Matoika (ID # 2290) – On Board and Miscellaneous Views |date=23 January 2008}}</ref>
[[File:Six crew members of R-38 aboard SS Princess Matoika.jpg|thumb|left|These six U.S. Navy [[Petty Officer#United States|Petty Officers]], posing on the deck of USAT ''Princess Matoika'', were part of a Navy group headed to attempt a transatlantic flight in the rigid airship ''[[R38 (ZR-2)|R38]]'' from the United Kingdom. [[Boatswain's Mate (US Navy)|Chief Boatswain's Mate]] M. Lay (front center) and [[Machinist's Mate|Chief Machinist's Mate]] W.A. Julius (rear left) were among the 45 men killed in the crash of the airship on 24 August 1921.]] In May 1920 ''Princess Matoika'' took on board the bodies of ten female nurses and over 400 soldiers who died while on duty in France during the war. The ship then transited the [[Kiel Canal]] and picked up 1,600 U.S. residents of [[Poland|Polish]] descent at [[Danzig]], all of whom had enlisted in the [[Polish Army]] at the outset of the war. Also included among the passengers were 500 U.S. soldiers who had been released from occupation duty at [[Koblenz]]. The ship arrived at New York on 23 May with little fanfare and no ceremony; bodies returned but not claimed by families were buried at [[Arlington National Cemetery]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Army transport brings both joy and sorrow home | work = The Atlanta Constitution | date = 24 May 1920 | page = 10 }} Also: {{cite news | title = Ship brings bodies of 10 war nurses | work = The Washington Post | date = 24 May 1920 | page = 2 }}</ref><!--facts from both article incorporated; other than the nurses, the other numbers did *not* match --> On 21 July, ''Princess Matoika'' arrived in New York after a similar voyage with 25 [[war bride]]s, many repatriated Polish troops among its 2,094 [[steerage]] passengers, and the remains of 881 soldiers.<ref>{{cite news | title = Bodies of 881 war heroes arrive from overseas | work = Chicago Daily Tribune | date = 22 July 1920 | page = 4 }}</ref> In between these two trips, the [[Belgium|Belgian]] Ambassador to the United States, [[Baron]] [[Emile de Cartier de Marchienne]], sailed from New York to Belgium on board the ''Matoika''.<ref>{{cite news | title = Belgian ambassador sails | work = [[The Christian Science Monitor]] | date = 7 June 1920 | page = 12 }}</ref> It was, however, ''Princess Matoika''{{'}}s next trip to Belgium that was the most infamous.
=== "Mutiny of the ''Matoika'' <!--"thin space" to prevent clash of italics with quotes-->" === {{Main article|Mutiny of the Matoika}}
Beginning 26 July 1920, a majority of the U.S. Olympic contingent destined for the [[1920 Summer Olympics]] in Antwerp, Belgium, endured a troubled transatlantic journey aboard ''Princess Matoika''. The voyage and the events onboard—later called the "Mutiny of the ''Matoika'' <!--"thin space" to prevent clash of italics with quotes-->"—were still being discussed in the popular press years later. The ''Matoika'' was a last-minute substitute for another ship and, according to the athletes, did not have adequate accommodations or training facilities on board.<ref name=Findling>Findling and Pelle, p. 56.</ref> Near the end of the voyage, the athletes published a list of grievances and demands and distributed copies of the document to the [[United States Secretary of War]], the [[United States Olympic Committee|American Olympic Committee]] members, and the press.<ref name=NYT-1920-08-08>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9F00E1DF1639E133A2575BC0A96E9C946195D6CF |format=pdf |title=Officials blamed by U.S. athletes |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=8 August 1920 |page=23}}</ref> The incident received wide coverage in American newspapers at the time.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B0DE6DD1339E133A25754C1A9629C946395D6CF |format=pdf |title=Colleges to fight A.A.U., says Fuessle |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=17 April 1922 |page=19}}</ref>
After the contingent of athletes [[:wikt:debarked|debarked]] at Antwerp on 8 August,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C07E5DB1E31E433A2575AC0A96E9C946195D6CF |format=pdf |title=U.S. athletes in Olympic quarters |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=9 August 1920 |page=14}}</ref> ''Princess Matoika'' made one more voyage of note while under U.S. Army control. The ''Matoika'' sailed for New York on 24 August and arrived on 4 September carrying a portion of the returning Olympic team,<ref name=WP-1920-09-05>{{cite news | title = American scouts win high honors | work = The Washington Post | date = 5 September 1920 | page = 28 }}<!--dates of sailing, arrival--></ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9906E1D81E31E433A25757C0A96F9C946195D6CF |format=pdf |title=Olympic team returning |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=4 September 1920 |page=13}}</ref> American [[Boy Scouting (Boy Scouts of America)|Boy Scouts]] returning from the [[1st World Scout Jamboree|International Boy Scout Jamboree]] in London,<ref name=WP-1920-09-05 /> and the remains of 1,284 American soldiers for repatriation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=940DE7DE173AE532A25756C0A96F9C946195D6CF |format=pdf |title=1,284 soldier dead arrive |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=5 September 1920 |page=15}}</ref>
== U.S. Mail Line == At the conclusion of her Army service, ''Princess Matoika'' was handed over to the {{USSB|first=long}}, who chartered the vessel to the [[United States Mail Steamship Company]] for service from New York to [[Italy]]. This solution of how to use the ''Princess'' for civilian service was the culmination of efforts by the {{USSB}} to find a suitable civilian use for her. In 1919, she was one of the ships suggested for a proposed service from [[New Orleans]], Louisiana, to [[Valparaiso]], Chile,<ref name=McIntosh>McIntosh, p. 20.</ref> and in November 1919, tentative plans were announced for her service with the [[Munson Line]] between New York and [[Argentina]] beginning in mid-1920,<ref>{{cite news | title = Two ships for Argentina | work = The Washington Post | date = 8 November 1919 | page = 6 }}</ref> but both of these proposals fell through.
[[File:SS Princess Alice iceberg postcard.jpg|thumb|right|SS ''Princess Alice'', in [[North German Lloyd]] livery, is depicted sailing among [[iceberg]]s in this pre-World War I postcard.]] ''Princess Matoika''—outfitted for 350 cabin-class and 500 third-class passengers and at {{GRT|10,421|disp=long}}—kicked off her U.S. Mail Line service on 20 January 1921 when she sailed from New York to [[Naples]] and [[Genoa]] on her first of three roundtrips between these ports.<ref name=Bonsor-v2-567 /> After a storm damaged the ''Matoika''{{'}}s steering gear, she had to be towed back in to New York on 28 January.<ref>{{cite news | title = Imperial and foreign news items |work=The Times | date = 1 February 1921 | page = 9 }}</ref>
After repairs and a successful eastbound crossing, ''Princess Matoika'' had an encounter with an [[iceberg]] off [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]] while carrying some 2,000 Italian immigrants on her first return trip from Italy. On the night of 24 February, the fully laden ship struck what was reported in ''[[The New York Times]]'' as either "an iceberg or a submerged wreck" off [[Cape Race]]. The ship's steering gear was damaged in the collision, leaving the ship adrift for over seven hours before repairs were effected. The ''Matoika''{{'}}s captain indicated that no passengers were hurt in the collision.<ref name=NYT-1920-02-27>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A07E7DC113FE432A25754C2A9649C946095D6CF |format=pdf |title=Liner, with 2,000 passengers, hits iceberg and drifts helplessly at sea seven hours |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=27 February 1921 |page=1}}</ref> According to the story of one third-class passenger, she, suspecting there was something seriously amiss, made inquiry after the commotion. A crew member told her that the ''Matoika'' had only stopped to greet a ship passing in the night. When she went on deck, insistent on seeing the other ship herself, she saw the iceberg and observed the first-class passengers queued up to board the already-lowered [[lifeboat (shipboard)|lifeboats]]. She took her daughter with her to join one of the queues, and, though initially rebuffed, was allowed to remain.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sea of Memories: Princess Matoika |url=http://www.maritimematters.com/princess-matoika-seamemory.html |website=Maritime Matters: Ocean liner history and cruise ship news |publisher=Martin Cox |date=December 1999 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080524185211/http://www.maritimematters.com/princess-matoika-seamemory.html |archivedate=24 May 2008}}</ref> The lifeboats were never deployed, however, and the ''Matoika'' arrived in Boston, where she had been diverted due to a [[typhus]] scare,<ref name=NYT-1920-02-27/> on 28 February without further incident.<ref>{{cite news | title = Immigrants arrive | work = The Christian Science Monitor | date = 1 March 1921 | page = 10 }}</ref>
On the ''Matoika''{{'}}s third and final return voyage from Italy, begun on 17 May,<ref name=Bonsor-v2-567 /> [[United States Customs Service|U.S. Customs Service]] agents at New York seized $150,000 worth of [[cocaine]]—along with valuable silks and jewels—being smuggled into the United States. Officials speculated that because of a maritime strike, members of a smuggling ring were able to infiltrate the crew of the ship.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9407E7D91739E133A25756C0A9609C946095D6CF |format=pdf |title=Seize $150,000 drug hidden in ash pail |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=5 June 1921 |page=10}}</ref>
After her withdrawal from the Italian route, ''Princess Matoika'' was transferred to New York–Bremen service, sailing on her first commercial trip to Germany since before World War I on 14 June.<ref name=Bonsor-v2-567 /> In July, during her second roundtrip on the Bremen route,<ref name=Bonsor-v2-567 /> late rental payments to the {{USSB}} resulted in action to seize the nine ships chartered by the U.S. Mail Line, including the ''Matoika'', after its return from Bremen. The ships were turned over to [[United American Lines]]—[[W. Averell Harriman]]'s steamship company—for temporary operation.<ref name=CDT-1921-07-24>{{cite news | title = Harriman lines to run 5 ships seized by U.S. | work = Chicago Daily Tribune | date = 24 July 1921 | page = 4 }}</ref> After some legal wrangling by both the {{USSB}} and the U.S. Mail Line—and in light of financial irregularities by the U.S. Mail Line that were uncovered—the ships were permanently retained by the {{USSB}} in August.<ref name=CDT-1921-08-28>{{cite news | title = Immigrants are robbed by ship firm—Lasker | work = Chicago Daily Tribune | date = 28 August 1921 | page = 3 }}</ref>
== United States Lines == Upon the formation of the United States Lines in August 1921, ''Princess Matoika'' and the eight other ex-German liners formerly operated by the U.S. Mail Line were transferred to the new company for operation.<ref>{{cite news | title = United States Lines will operate passenger vessels |work=The Wall Street Journal | date = 30 August 1921 | page = 8 }}</ref> The ''Princess'', still on New York–Bremen service, sailed on her first voyage for the new steamship line on 15 September.<ref name=Bonsor-v2-567 /> In October, ''Matoika'' crewmen were reported as taking advantage of the [[Inflation in the Weimar Republic|German inflation]] by consuming champagne available for $1.00 per quart and mugs of "the best beer" for an American penny.<ref>{{cite news | title = Champagne and beer add joys to U.S. sailor's life | work = Chicago Daily Tribune | date = 17 October 1921 | page = 1 }}</ref> In November, United States Lines announced that ''Princess Matoika'' would be replaced on the Bremen route in order to better compete with [[North German Lloyd]], the liner's former owner, but that never came about.<!-- See Bonsor for continuation of Bremen service --><ref name=Bonsor-v2-567 /><ref>{{cite news | title = To build up Atlantic service | work = The Wall Street Journal | date = 8 November 1921 | page = 3 }}<!-- announcement--></ref> The ''Princess'' continued on runs to Bremen, calling at the additional ports of [[Cobh|Queenstown]], [[Southampton]], and [[Danzig]], as her schedule shifted from time to time.<ref name=Bonsor-v2-567 />
On 28 January 1922, the ''Matoika'' departed with 400 passengers, among them, 312 [[Poland|Polish]] orphans headed for repatriation in their homeland.<ref name = WP-1922-01-31/> Two days and {{convert|100|nmi|km}} out of New York, the liner experienced a heavy [[gale]] that disabled her steering gear, and forced her return to New York after temporary repairs failed.<ref name=WP-1922-01-31>{{cite news | title = Matoika, 312 orphans aboard, limps to port | work = The Washington Post | date = 31 January 1922 | page = 17 }}</ref> The captain was able to steer her through the use of the ship's engines,<ref name=WP-1922-01-31 /> and arrived safely back in port on 31 January.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D06EEDA1130EE3ABC4953DFB4668389639EDE |format=pdf |title=Damaged ship returns |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=1 February 1922 |page=17}}</ref> This incident was the yet another misfortune that had befallen the young Poles. After being orphaned by the fighting between Polish and [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] forces, the orphans had been taken across [[Siberia]], evacuated to Japan, transported to [[Seattle]], Washington, and taken by rail to Chicago, Illinois, where they were enrolled in school while searches for relatives in Poland were conducted.<ref name=WP-1922-01-22>{{cite news | title = Polish orphans going home | work = The Washington Post | date = 22 January 1922 | page = 31 }}</ref>
[[File:Chester A Arthur by Daniel Huntington.jpeg|left|thumb|upright|[[Chester A. Arthur]], the 21st [[List of Presidents of the United States|U.S. President]], was the namesake for ''President Arthur'']] After four Bremen roundtrips for United States Lines, ''Princess Matoika'' had sailed her last voyage under that name.<ref name=Bonsor-v2-567 /> When newly built Type 535 vessels named for American presidents came into service for the company in May 1922, the ''Princess'' was renamed SS ''President Arthur'' in honor of the 21st [[List of Presidents of the United States|U.S. President]], [[Chester A. Arthur]], matching the naming style of the new ships.<ref name=Drechsel-v1-339>Drechsel, Vol. 1, p. 339</ref>
After her rename, she continued plying the North Atlantic between New York and Bremen, and was involved in a few episodes of note during this time. In June 1922, two years into [[Prohibition in the United States]], ''President Arthur'' was raided while at her dock in Hoboken, New Jersey, which netted 150 cases of smuggled spirits. Officials involved denied reports that the raid was conducted as a legal [[Test case (law)|test case]] intended to test the determination of {{USSB}} chair [[Albert Lasker]] that United States-flagged ships could carry and sell alcohol outside the [[three-mile limit|three-mile territorial limit]] of the United States.<ref>{{cite news | author = [[Associated Press]] | title = American ships raided | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 28 June 1922 | page = I-1 }}</ref> Congressman [[James A. Gallivan]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[Massachusetts|MA]]), an anti-prohibition leader, publicly demanded to know why the ship had not been seized for violating U.S. laws.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A01E0D71231EF33A2575AC2A9609C946395D6CF |format=pdf |title=Fight on 'wet' ships laid to foreigners |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=29 June 1922 |page=16}}</ref>
In September, ''President Arthur'' carried [[Irish republicanism|Irish republicans]] Muriel MacSwiney, widow of the recently deceased [[Lord Mayor of Cork]] [[Terence MacSwiney]], and Linda Mary Kearns, who had been jailed for murder under the [[Black and Tans]], to New York. Wearing buttons with pictures of [[Harry Boland]], an anti-[[Anglo-Irish Treaty|treaty]] Irish nationalist who had been killed the previous month, the two women were there to raise funds for orphans of [[Irish Republican Army (1922–1969)|Anti-Treaty IRA]] forces, who were then fighting in southern Ireland.<ref>{{cite news | title = Finance Collins killers | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 7 September 1922 | page = I-1 }}</ref> In October, a Hoboken man, after securing a last-minute [[court order]], was able to halt the deportation of his German niece on ''President Arthur''; she was retrieved from the ship ten minutes before sailing time.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9506E1DC1139E133A25750C1A9669D946395D6CF |format=pdf |title=Halts girl's deportation |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=13 October 1922 |page=16}}</ref>
In November 1922, U.S. Customs Service agents, seized a cache of [[Colt's Manufacturing Company|Colt]] [[Magazine (firearms)|magazine]] guns aboard ''President Arthur''. The entire crew was questioned but all denied any knowledge of the eight weapons found stowed behind a [[bulkhead (partition)|bulkhead]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A02EFDD1638EF3ABC4052DFB7678389639EDE |format=pdf |title=Find 8 magazine guns hidden in liner's hold |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=18 November 1922 |page=3 }}</ref> In August the following year, ''President Arthur'' took on board a seaman suffering from [[pneumonia]] from the [[Norway|Norwegian]] freighter ''Eastern Star'' in a mid-ocean transfer. The ship's doctor and nurse attended to the sailor but were unable to save him.<ref>{{cite news |title=Transfer sailor at sea |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=23 August 1923 |page=2}}</ref>
''President Arthur'' sailed on her last transatlantic voyage from Bremen on 18 October 1923,<ref name=Bonsor-v2-567 /> carrying 656 passengers to New York.<ref name=NYT-1923-10-31>{{cite news |title=Ellis Island full, faces new influx |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0F10FE3A5417738DDDA80B94D8415B838EF1D3 |format=pdf |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=31 October 1923 |page=19 |subscription=yes}}</ref> Anchoring off [[Gravesend, Brooklyn|Gravesend Bay]] on 30 October, ''President Arthur'' was one of 15 passenger ships whose arrival in New York was timed to coincide with the opening of the November immigration quota period.<ref name=NYT-1923-10-31 /> Under the [[Emergency Quota Act]] passed in 1921, numerical limits on European immigration were imposed which created nationality quotas.<ref>Higham, p. 311.</ref> At the conclusion of this voyage, ''President Arthur'' was [[:wikt:laid up|laid up]] in [[Baltimore]], Maryland, for almost a year.<ref name=Drechsel-v1-339 />
== American Palestine Line == {{Main article|American Palestine Line}} [[File:American Palestine Line house flag.svg|right|thumb|The flag of the American Palestine Line]] On 9 October 1924, the newly formed [[American Palestine Line]] announced that it had purchased ''President Arthur'' from the {{USSB|first=nolink}}, with plans to inaugurate service between New York and [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] the following March. The American Palestine Line was formed in 1924 for the purpose of providing direct passenger service from New York to Palestine and was reportedly the first steamship company owned and operated by Jews.<ref name=NYT-1924-10-10>{{cite news |title=Zionists to run fleet |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=10 October 1924 |page=21}}</ref> The company had negotiated to purchase three [[ocean liner]]s from the {{USSB}} but was only able to purchase ''President Arthur''.<ref>Davis, p. 148.</ref> After refurbishing the liner,<ref name=NYT-1925-03-08 /> the company inaugurated service between New York and Palestine in March 1925, when ''President Arthur'' sailed on her maiden voyage. A crowd of 15,000 witnessed ceremonies that included songs, prayers, and speeches in English and [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]].<ref name=NYT-1925-03-08 /> The company claimed that ''President Arthur'' was the first ocean liner to fly the [[Flag of Israel|Zionist flag]] at sea,<ref name=NYT-1925-03-13>{{cite news |title=Palestine liner gets big send-off |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=13 March 1925 |page=8}}</ref> and the first ocean liner ever to have female officers.<ref>{{cite news |title=Capt. W. J. Breen, S. S. President Arthur, has commissioned... |type=photo caption |newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=17 March 1925 |page=9}}</ref>
The line had labor difficulties and financial difficulties throughout its existence. Rumors of a mutiny during ''President Arthur''{{'}}s first trip were reported in ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref>{{cite news |title=Big police squad meets Jewish ship |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=9 May 1925 |page=6}}</ref> and several crew members got into an altercation with members of the [[Blackshirts]], the Italian fascist paramilitary group, when the liner made an intermediary stop in [[Naples]].<ref>{{cite news | title = American seamen clash with fascisti | work = The Washington Post | date = 24 April 1925 | page = 1 }}</ref> On her second voyage, the ship's [[master-at-arms]] was killed by a fellow crew member.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kills master-at-arms on President Arthur |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=24 June 1925 |page=2}}</ref> Financial difficulties included unpaid bills and resultant court actions, and accusations of fraud against company officers that were leveled in the press.<ref name = NYT-1925-12-04/> In late 1925 the company was placed in the hands of a [[receiver (legal)|receiver]],<ref name=NYT-1925-12-04>{{cite news |title=Say Palestine Line got bond by fraud |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=4 December 1925 |page=11}}</ref><ref name=NYT-1925-09-12>{{cite news |title=Palestine ship line in receiver's hands |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=12 September 1925 |page=7}}</ref> ''President Arthur''—after a two-alarm fire in her forward cargo hold<ref>{{cite news |title=Fire on President Arthur |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=20 September 1925 |page=28}}</ref>—ended up back in the hands of the {{USSB}},<ref name=LAT-1926-08-19>{{cite news | title = Local yard to rebuild liner | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 19 August 1926 | page = 10 }}</ref> and the company's office furniture and fixtures were sold at auction in early 1926.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bankruptcy sales |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=24 February 1926 |page=38}}</ref>
== Los Angeles Steamship Company == In August 1926 the {{LASSCO|first=long}} announced the acquisition of ''President Arthur'' from the {{USSB}}.<!-- "from the USSB" --><ref name=LAT-1926-08-19 /><ref name=LAT-1926-08-18>{{cite news | title = New ship for island run | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 18 August 1926 | page = A1 }}</ref> The liner would be extensively rebuilt and then sail opposite of {{SS|City of Los Angeles|1922|2}} (the former North German Lloyd liner ''Grosser Kurfürst''<ref>{{cite DANFS | title = Aeolus | url = http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/a3/aeolus-i.htm | short = yes }}</ref>) on a Los Angeles–Hawaii route.<ref name=LAT-1926-08-18 /> Arriving from New York on 24 September, the ship was docked at [[Los Angeles Shipbuilding and Drydock]] to immediately begin a $2,500,000 refit.<ref name=LAT-1926-09-25>{{cite news | title = New liner here for Hawaii run | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 25 September 1926 | page = A7 }}The value of the refit given in newspaper accounts ranged from $1.3–$3.0 million; $2.5 million was the most commonly reported amount.<!-- LA Shipbuilding details --></ref><ref name=LAT-1927-05-15>{{cite news | title = Liner off on trial trip | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 15 May 1927 | page = B1 }}<!-- "final" cost of refit --></ref> Although initially planned to be ready for February 1927 sailings,<ref name=LAT-1926-09-25 /> progress was slowed by drydock access, and her completion date was pushed to May.<ref>{{cite news | title = Liner overhaul work is rushed | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 12 February 1927 | page = 17 }}</ref> During her refit, the ship was renamed ''City of Honolulu'',<ref>{{cite news | title = Ship to be rechristened | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 23 September 1926 | page = A11 }}</ref> becoming the second {{LASSCO}} ship of that name.<ref><!--footnote-->The prior {{SS|City of Honolulu|1896|2}} was the former [[North German Lloyd]] liner ''Friedrich der Grosse'', the first of the {{sclass|Barbarossa|ocean liner|4}} launched, which had burned and sunk on her maiden voyage for {{LASSCO}} in October 1922.</ref> At the conclusion of her reconstruction in May, ''City of Honolulu'' sailed on a 24-hour shakedown cruise.<ref name=LAT-1927-05-15 />
=== Maiden voyage === ''City of Honolulu'' was rebuilt to {{GRT|10,680}} and had accommodations for around 450 first-class and 50 third-class passengers.<ref name=Drechsel-v1-339 /> Her hull was painted all white for {{LASSCO}} service, and she sported period designs in her common areas. The dining room, large enough to seat 300 in a single sitting, was decorated in a [[Greek Revival architecture|Grecian]] theme,<ref name=LAT-1927-05-15 /> and featured 18 [[stained glass window]]s designed by San Diego architect [[Carleton Winslow]].<ref name=LAT-1927-06-04>{{cite news | title = Ocean palace to sail today | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 4 June 1927 | page = A1 }}</ref> The [[smoking room]] was done up in a [[Tudor style architecture|Tudor style]]; the music room was decorated in a combined [[Second Empire (architecture)|French]] and [[Italianate architecture|Italian]] Renaissance manner; and the writing room was in [[Adam style]]. The [[suite (hotel)|suites]] were all done in either Adam, [[Queen Anne Style architecture|Queen Anne]], or [[Louis XVI style|Louis XVI]] styles.<ref name=LAT-1927-05-15 /> The ship featured six passenger elevators,<ref name=LAT-1927-06-04 /> and a swimming pool patterned on a [[Pompei]]an design. One of the few remaining traces of her pre-war German decoration was the [[rosewood]] railing on her grand staircase.<ref name=LAT-1927-06-04 />
On 4 June 1927, a crowd of 7,000 well-wishers saw ''City of Honolulu'' depart on her maiden voyage. The festivities were also broadcast on radio station KGFO,<ref name=LAT-1927-06-05>{{cite news | title = Palatial liner off on voyage | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 5 June 1927 | page = B5 }}</ref> a portable station operating form the front cargo deck of the ship. During the journey, broadcasts of the ''City of Honolulu''{{'}}s orchestra, along with radio personalities and musicians from Los Angeles station [[KHJ (AM)|KHJ]], entertained both passengers and listeners on shore (while the ship was in range).<ref name=LAT-1927-06-26>{{cite news | title = Broadcast programs in mid-Pacific | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 26 June 1927 | page = B6 }} Brant Radio Power Co., the owners of KGFO, were granted special permission from the [[Federal Radio Commission]] to transmit from their broadcast truck aboard the ship while at sea, and while ashore at Hawaii.</ref>
Several notable passengers sailed on the liner's maiden voyage. [[Jay Gould II]], tennis champion and grandson of railroad [[tycoon]] [[Jay Gould]], sailed for a three-month stay at his Hawaiian home.<ref name=LAT-1927-06-04 /><ref name=LAT-1927-09-17>{{cite news | title = Jay Gould here on trip to east | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 17 September 1927 | page = A1 }}<!--length of stay--></ref> Also sailing were movie star [[Laura La Plante]] and her husband, director [[William A. Seiter]],<ref name=LAT-1927-06-04 /> and, [[Western Auto]] founder [[George Pepperdine]], who began a three-month tour of the [[Orient]] with his daughters.<ref name=LAT-1927-06-04 /><ref name=LAT-1927-09-17 /><!-- length of stay, daughters --> On arrival in Honolulu on 10 June, ''City of Honolulu'' was adorned with flowers and received a welcome from airplanes and a flotilla of [[outrigger canoe]]s that escorted her into the harbor.<ref>{{cite news | title = New liner welcomed at islands | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 11 June 1927 | page = 1 }}</ref> After a ten-day stay in the islands,<ref name=LAT-1927-06-05 /> she departed for Los Angeles, returning there on 26 June.<ref name=LAT-1927-06-26 />
[[File:Maui coast panorama.jpg|thumb|left|On ''City of Honolulu''{{'}}s passage from [[Hilo, Hawaii|Hilo]] to [[Honolulu]], travelers would have seen a view of [[Maui]] similar to this one, taken from the [[ʻAuʻau Channel]] in December 2007.]]
=== Career === After completion of her maiden voyage, ''City of Honolulu'' began regular service from Los Angeles to Honolulu and [[Hilo, Hawaii|Hilo]] on what {{LASSCO}} called the "Great Circle Route of Sunshine". After arriving at Honolulu, the ship would sail southeast to Hilo, passing the islands of [[Molokai]] and [[Maui]] on their north sides. On the return from Hilo, the liner would traverse the [[ʻAlalākeiki Channel|ʻAlalākeiki]], the [[ʻAuʻau Channel|ʻAuʻau]], and the [[Kalohi Channel]]s, taking the ship between Maui and Molokai on the north and the islands of [[Kahoolawe]] and [[Lanai]] on the south.<ref name=timetable-map>{{cite web |url=http://www.timetableimages.com/maritime/images/lasscoi.htm |title=Hawaii direct from Los Angeles |type=brochure and timetable |date=February 1927 |publisher=Los Angeles Steamship Company}} (Convenience copy located at [http://www.timetableimages.com/maritime/index.htm Maritime Timetable Images].)</ref>
Throughout her career, ''City of Honolulu'' transported many notable passengers to Hawaii. In July 1927, for example, [[Henry Smith Pritchett]], president of the [[The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching|Carnegie Foundation]], sailed to Hawaii en route to a meeting with the [[Institute of Pacific Relations]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Shipping and Los Angeles Harbor news | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 2 July 1927 | page = 15 }}</ref> In June 1928, movie stars [[Norma Talmadge]], [[Gilbert Roland]], and [[Lottie Pickford]] began a Hawaiian vacation,<ref>{{cite news | title = Shipping news and activities at Los Angeles Harbor | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 2 June 1928 | page = 7 }}</ref> and on 28 July, [[Jane Addams]], the founder of [[Hull House]] and a pioneer of the [[settlement movement]], headed there as well. Addams was on her way to attend the Pan-Pacific Women's Conference and the congress of the [[Women's International League for Peace and Freedom]]; a former [[List of Governors of Hawaii|Governor of Hawaii]], [[Walter F. Frear]], returned to the islands on that same voyage.<ref>{{cite news | title = Busy week-end due at harbor | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 28 July 1928 | page = 15 }}</ref> In December, [[Al Jolson]] and his wife, [[Ruby Keeler]], sailed on the liner for a vacation,<ref>{{cite news | title = Bookings heavy for Hawaii trip | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 15 December 1928 | page = A16 }}</ref> and early the next February, the reigning [[The Open Championship|British Open]] golf champion, [[Walter Hagen]], sailed to start a four-month golfing tour and exhibition in Australia. Hagan was accompanied by Australian golfer [[Joe Kirkwood, Sr.|Joe Kirkwood]];<ref>{{cite news | title = Hagen sails for Hawaii | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 2 February 1930 | page = E12 }}</ref> [[Arctic explorer]] [[Donald B. MacMillan]] also left for Hawaii on the same sailing.<ref>{{cite news | last = Cave | first = Wayne B | title = Hawaii travel gain indicated | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 31 January 1930 | page = 19 }}</ref>
[[File:AlohaTowerAtNight.jpg|upright|thumb|right|[[Aloha Tower]] at [[Honolulu Harbor]] welcomed the ''City of Honolulu'' and her passengers on their arrival in Hawaii.]] ''City of Honolulu'' also carried notable visitors to the [[Continental United States|mainland]]. Farris M. Brown, a dealer in [[Stradivarius|Stradivarius instruments]], arrived in Los Angeles in May 1928 with three of the famous maker's violins, including the [[Baron Knoop Stradivarius]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Glorified peddler debarks | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 26 May 1928 | page = A6 }}</ref> In April 1929, [[Sweden|Swedish]] swimmer [[Arne Borg]], accompanied by his wife, arrived in Los Angeles on a world swimming tour,<ref>{{cite news | title = Borg visitor in Southland | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 27 April 1929 | page =10 }}</ref> and in May, Sir [[James Gunnson]], a former [[Mayor of Auckland]], arrived for a one-month visit to promote increased trade between California and New Zealand.<ref>{{cite news | title = Original booster for city arrives | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 25 May 1929 | page = A1 }}</ref> The next January, [[Herbert James Hagerman|Herbert Hagerman]], former [[List of Governors of New Mexico Territory|Governor of New Mexico Territory]]; author [[Basil Woon]], who had been doing research for a Hawaiian story; and aviation promoter and chewing gum magnate [[William Edward Easterwood|William Easterwood]] all sailed stateside on the ship.<ref>{{cite news | last = Cave | first = Wayne B | title = Shipping news and activities at Los Angeles Harbor | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 4 January 1930 | page = 7 }}</ref>
Apart from notable passengers carried during her tenure, ''City of Honolulu'' also frequently served as a conveyance for newlyweds heading for Hawaiian honeymoons.<ref>See, for example, "Sundays on new honeymoon", ''Los Angeles Times'', 7 May 1928, p. A11; and "Honeymooners 'in the same boat'", ''Los Angeles Times'', 27 August 1928, p. A1.</ref> She also carried, in addition to passengers, cargo in both directions, transporting commodities, such as fertilizer and oil, to Hawaii,<ref name=LAT-1930-05-26>{{cite news | title = Local liner in flames | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 26 May 1930 | page = 1 }}</ref> and Hawaiian goods, like sugar and fresh and canned pineapple to the mainland.<ref>See, for example, "Excursionists land today", ''Los Angeles Times'', 18 August 1928, p. A9.</ref>
=== Fire and scrapping === ''City of Honolulu''{{'}}s career as a tropical liner, however, was short-lived. On the afternoon of 25 May 1930, just shy of completing three years of {{LASSCO}} service, a fire broke out on her B deck while she was docked in her namesake city. Although aided by [[fireboat Leleiona|fireboat ''Leleiona'']] and U.S. Navy submarine rescue ship {{USS|Widgeon|ASR-1|2}}, firefighters were unable to bring the blaze under control quickly, and it spread to {{convert|100|ST|t}} of [[potash]] aboard the liner. Fears that her cargo of {{convert|16000|oilbbl}} of oil would explode caused firefighters to intentionally sink the liner at her pier in order to help extinguish the conflagration.<ref name=LAT-1930-05-26 /> Through firefighters' efforts, the fire was contained to the upper three decks, leaving the ship's power plant relatively undamaged.<ref name=LAT-1930-06-11>{{cite news | last = Drake | first = Waldo | title = Lassco's liner due in dry dock | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 11 June 1930 | page = 11 }}</ref> All crew members and {{LASSCO}} employees on board the ship got off safely; no passengers were on the ship at the time of the fire.<ref>{{cite news | author = [[Associated Press]] | title = Burned liner's crew all safe | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 27 May 1930 | page = 4 }}</ref>
The ship was pumped out and raised on 9 June, and taken to the naval drydock at [[Pearl Harbor]] for inspection on 12 June.<ref name=LAT-1930-06-11 /> While remaining in Hawaii, one engine was restored to working order and the ship departed for Los Angeles under her own power on 30 October. After her arrival, further inspections were conducted, and it was determined that repairs would be too expensive, especially given the [[Great Depression|global economic conditions]]. ''City of Honolulu'' was declared a total loss,<ref name=Drechsel-v1-339 /> and was laid up in the West Basin of Los Angeles Harbor for almost three years.<ref name=LAT-1932-12-20>{{cite news | last = Cave | first = Wayne B | title = Shipping news and activities at Los Angeles Harbor | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 20 December 1932 | page = 13 }}</ref> During her lay up, fittings and fixtures stripped from the vessel were auctioned in July 1932,<ref>{{cite news |title=Steamship salvage auction... |type=display advertisement |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=31 July 1932 |page=11}}</ref> and in December, film crews from [[Columbia Pictures|Columbia Pictures Corporation]] spent ten days filming on board the ship.<!-- no indication in refs as to what the film was. My OR points towards "Fog", a 1933 release from Columbia set on board a ship --><ref name=LAT-1932-12-20 />
''City of Honolulu'' was sold to Japanese [[ship breaking|shipbreakers]] in mid 1933,<ref name=LAT-1933-08-02>{{cite news | last = Drake | first = Waldo | title = Two old liners to be scrapped | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 2 August 1933 | page = 6 }}</ref> and—in the company of {{SS|Calawaii||2}}, another {{LASSCO}} ship destined for the scrap heap—the ''City of Honolulu'' departed Los Angeles in late August under her own power.<ref name=Drechsel-v1-339 /> Manned by a [[Philippines|Filipino]] crew,<ref name=LAT-1933-08-02 /> the 33-year-old liner developed a problem with one of her boilers almost immediately and had to put in to San Francisco for repairs. Getting underway after a lengthy delay, one of her engines failed in mid-ocean, leaving her to plod on to Japan on one engine.<ref name=LAT-1933-09-29>{{cite news | last = Drake | first = Waldo | title = Hopes for deep fairway rise | work = Los Angeles Times | date = 29 September 1933 | page = 17 }}</ref> She eventually arrived in [[Osaka]] at the shipbreaker in mid-December, and was scrapped shortly thereafter.<ref name=Drechsel-v1-339 />
